hackathon-description-text: On the weekend of October 5, over 1,000 hackers from all over the world will gather at MIT for a hackathon like no other. 1000+ people, $10k+ prizes, 30 hours. October 5-6, 2013 at MIT. Open to all students, all schools. Will you be there?
hackathon-eligibility:
Registered attendees of HackMIT
All undergraduate students from any university in any country are welcome. High school students must be 18 or older to attend. This event is closed to graduate students. (Shouldn't you be working on your thesis anyway?)
You must
hackathon-rules:
- YOU MUST BE AT HackMIT TO WORK ON A PROJECT FOR SUBMISSION
- We strongly discourage building off of existing projects you've worked on. To be fair to others, let us know if you are using some of your old code in your hacks. Using third-party APIs and libraries is definitely okay, as long as they're accessible by everyone else as well.
- You cannot steal another team's source code
- The decision of judges is final for determining prizes and awards
- Please comply with all instructions from HackMIT organizers

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: $1k cash + additional items; TBD for 2nd and 3rd place finishers

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: SendGrid - Best use of SendGrid API Award

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: A Cow, A Water Buffalo, and a Llama for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place, to be donated to a family in the third world on the winner's behalf, through Heifer International
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Amicus - What Does The Fox Say? Award
Weather Underground - Best use of Weather Underground API Award

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: MongoDB swag and additional prize money

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Bloomberg - Best Use of the Bloomberg API

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Priority review of the 2014 fellowship application, travel and lodging to an upcoming Under 20 Summit, and a meet and greet with reps from the leadership council
Constant Contact swag kits (jacket, hat, etc), a featured story on our tech blog, and your app featured in our marketplace (if sass)
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Constant Contact - Best use of Constant Contact API
AlchemyAPI - Best Use of AlchemyAPI Award

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Samsung Galaxy S4 for each team member
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Synaptics, Inc. - Most Innovative project with ForcePad - 1st Prize

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Samsung Galaxy S4 for each team member
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Synaptics, Inc. - Most Innovative project with Hover - 1st Prize
Synaptics, Inc. - Most Innovative project with ForcePad - 2nd Prize
Synaptics, Inc. - Most Innovative project with Hover - 2nd Prize
Square Inc. - Making Commerce Easy and Rounding the Corners

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: An invitation to come and pitch to the Rough Draft Ventures team (chance of up to $25k investment) and/or dinner with our team and local VCs
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: General Catalyst - Most likely to be the “Next Big Thing”

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: BIG JAMBOXs or Jawbone UPs for the entire team.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Jawbone - For the best health hack

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: One iPad mini (retail value: $400), and four memory sticks pre-loaded with purchased,  premium, high resolution historical pricing data for every U.S. stock, major commodity, and currency pair, going back to 1990 (retail value: $10,000).

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Bain Capital: Best Use of Data Visualization
Bain Capital: Best Use of Machine Learning

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Is the hack practical? Is it something people would actually use? Does it fulfill a real need people have?
Is the hack more than just another generic social/mobile/local app? Does it do something entirely novel, or at least take a fresh approach to an old problem?
Is the hack technically interesting or difficult? Is it just some lipstick on an API, or were there real technical challenges to surmount?
Is the hack usable in its current state? Is the user experience smooth? Does everything appear to work? Is it well designed?

hackathon-location-address: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA
